text:
Willowbrook Road, east side, at Hall Avenue, showing the old J. Hall gun factory (Butler's 1853 map). It later (Beers's 1874 map) became the Hall hardware manufactory. The water that supplied the mill with power came from a small pond, known as Gun Factory Pond, and Willow Brook.

Between 1890 and 1898

From P. L. Sperr Collection

(1)

Willowbrook Road, east side, at Hall Avenue, showing the old gun factory on the J. Hall property. The factory was operated by water power derived from a samll pond and Willow
Brook.

1897

Photo by August Loeffler
From Staten Island Museum Collection through P. L. Sperr

(2)

The gun factory dam, many years later.

May 10, 1928

P. L. Sperr

(1)

Willowbrook Road, east side, at Hall Avenue, showing the old gun factory on the J. Hall property. The factory was operated by water power derived from a samll pond and Willow
Brook.

1897

Photo by August Loeffler
From Staten Island Museum Collection through P. L. Sperr

(2)

The gun factory dam, many years later.

May 10, 1928

P. L. Sperr

(1) Hall Ave. (formerly Darcys Lane), north side, 200 feet west of Willowbrook Road. The maps of 1874, 1887 and 1898 show it to have belonged to Mrs. Bean. The map of 1907 shows the house to have belonged to Boehm, and the 1917 map has the name of Margaret Bean.

October 18, 1922.
By Wm. T. Davis through P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, at a later date.

May 23, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

Hall Ave. (formerly Darcys Lane), south side, 200 feet west of Willowbrook Road, showing a pastoral scene on the old Dennis Darcy farm. Views 1 and 2 were taken the same day.

June 20, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

Hall Ave. (formerly Darcys Lane), south side, 200 feet west of Willowbrook Road, showing a pastoral scene on the old Dennis Darcy farm. Views 1 and 2 were taken the same day.

June 20, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

Hall Ave. (formerly Darcys Lane), south side, 200 feet west of Willowbrook Road, showing the old Darcy (or Darcey) House. It was the property of L.W. Darcey (1874-1887 maps); the L.W. Darcey estate (1898 map); and that of Dennis Darcy (1917 map). P. L. Sperr states that the house is said to be about 135 years old. This is a set of two views taken the same day.

May 23, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

Hall Ave. (formerly Darcys Lane), south side, 200 feet west of Willowbrook Road, showing the old Darcy (or Darcey) House. It was the property of L.W. Darcey (1874-1887 maps); the L.W. Darcey estate (1898 map); and that of Dennis Darcy (1917 map). P. L. Sperr states that the house is said to be about 135 years old. This is a set of two views taken the same day.

May 23, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Hall Ave. (formerly Darcys Lane), south side, 200 feet west of Willowbrook Road, showing the old Darcy (or Darcey) House. Beers' maps of 1874 and 1887 show it to have belonged to L.W. Darcey. Robinson's 1898 map indicates it as the property of the L.W. Darcy Estate, and the 1917 map shows it to be the Dennis Darcy property. P. L. Sperr states that the house is said to be about 135 years old.

May 23, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, at a later date.

April 28, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) A view of the west side of the house.

May 10, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

May 10, 1928.
